'''Inflection''' is a big-data technology company with products that allow users to search for and retrieve public documents and manage their [[online identity]].<ref name="AU">{{cite web |url=http://inflection.com/about/ |title=About Us |date= |author= |publisher=Inflection |accessdate=May 1,2013}}</ref><ref name="CB">{{cite web |url=http://www.crunchbase.com/company/inflection |title=Inflection |date= |author= |publisher=Crunchbase |accessdate=May 1,2013}}</ref> Inflection is best known for providing individuals and organizations with tools for searching public records from a database of over 14 billion [[public records]].<ref name="CB"/><ref name="BJ">{{cite web |url=http://www.bizjournals.com/sanjose/print-edition/2011/11/18/inflection-sees-big-opportunities-in.html |title=Inflection sees big opportunities in Big Data |date=November 18, 2011 |author=Jon Xavier |publisher=Silicon Valley Business Journal |accessdate=May 1,2013}}</ref> Inflection has been featured in several media outlets, including [[MSNBC]], [[TechCrunch]], [[The New Yorker]], [[The Wall Street Journal]], and [[The Los Angeles Times]].<ref name="INF">{{cite web |url=http://inflection.com/about/press.html |title=In The Press |date= |author= |publisher=Inflection |accessdate=May 1,2013}}</ref><ref name="CB"/><ref name="TC">{{cite web |url=http://techcrunch.com/2012/04/25/ancestry-com-acquires-archives-com-from-inflection-for-100-million/ |title=Ancestry.com Acquires Archives.com For $100 Million |date=April 25, 2012 |author=Frederic Lardinois |publisher=TechCrunch |accessdate=May 1,2013}}</ref><ref name="WSJ">{{cite web |url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424053111904800304576476552817595120.html |title=Employers Recruiting Off-Campus |date=August 4, 2011 |author=Samuel Wieghly |publisher=The Wall Street Journal |accessdate=May 1,2013}}</ref>
The company is headquartered in [[Redwood City, CA]] with offices in [[Omaha, NE]].<ref name="CB"/> Co-founder Matthew Monahan is Inflection’s [[CEO]].<ref name="MGM">{{cite web |url=http://inflection.com/about/leadership.html |title=Leadership Page |date= |author= |publisher=Inflection |accessdate=May 1,2013}}</ref><ref name="BJ"/>
==History== Brothers Matthew Monahan and Brian Monahan founded Inflection in 2006.<ref name="MGM"/><ref name="CB"/><ref name="AU"/> Their idea for the company was to create a resource where users could seek information from public records through a centralized, searchable platform.<ref name="BJ"/> The pair launched Inflection from a [[Harvard]] dorm room, and they bootstrapped the company’s finances for the first four years.<ref name="CB"/><ref name="BJ"/>
In 2010, Inflection raised $30 million in Series A [[venture financing]], which included capital from [[Matrix Partners]] and [[Sutter Hill Ventures]].<ref name="CB"/><ref name="WSJ2">{{cite web |url=http://blogs.wsj.com/venturecapital/2010/09/02/inflection-lands-big-first-round-for-public-records-search/ |title=Inflection Lands Big First Round For Public Records Search |date=September 2, 2010 |author=Tomio Geron |publisher=The Wall Street Journal |accessdate=May 1,2013}}</ref> The company now operates three main websites, the people search engine PeopleSmart.com, the online [[identity management]] site Identity.com, and the pre-employment background screening site GoodHire.com.<ref name="BJ"/> Inflection sold its genealogy site Archives.com to [[Ancestry.com]] in April 2012 for $100 million.<ref name="TC"/><ref name="BJ"/>
The founders chose the company’s name as a metaphor for the present state of the Internet and its impact on the world, which the founders believe is at a turning point comparable to the inflection point on the graph of a curve.<ref name="AU"/><ref name="THC">{{cite web |url=http://www.thecrimson.com/article/2011/3/24/monahan-inflection-sundquist-college/ |title=Startup Aims to Digitize Records |date=March 24, 2011 |author=Matthew T. Lowe |publisher=The Harvard Crimson |accessdate=May 1,2013}}</ref>
As of April 2013, Inflection employs approximately 150 people.<ref name="CB"/>
==Products== The company’s flagship products, [[PeopleSmart|PeopleSmart.com]], [http://www.Identity.com/ Identity.com], and [http://www.goodhire.com/ GoodHire.com] are powered by Inflection’s proprietary big-data platform STORM.<ref name="THC"/>
The platform allows users of Inflection’s products to search and retrieve over 14 billion records, including court records, contact information, and [[criminal records]].<ref name="AU"/><ref name="CB"/> The company emphasizes privacy, and users are able to [[opt out]] and remove their information from the websites.<ref name="WSJ2"/> For example, the company does not provide individuals’ email addresses or cell phone numbers to its customers.<ref name="WSJ2"/>
